security: Disclosing that Kay Lowe Huff's journalistic activity resulted in Agency publicity, specifically regarding Brazilian police torture tactics, could damage the CIA's reputation. "Note: As a member of the news media field [Huff] has been involved in journalistic activity resulting in Agency publicity. Specifically, [Huff] filed a story in which he endeavored to explain why some Brazilians have thought that the United States Government and this Agency have been involved in Brazilian police torture tactics."
summary: This document provides information on Maria Louise Phillips, Kay Lowe Huff, and Virginia Louise Simmons Phillips, detailing operational approvals for Huff and contract employment approval for Phillips, which was later cancelled.
summary_one_paragraph: This record, dated September 13, 1972, contains background information on individuals associated with the CIA. It notes that Kay Lowe Huff received operational approvals in August 1969, 1970, and 1971, and that Huff's journalistic activities resulted in Agency publicity due to a story he filed explaining Brazilian perceptions of U.S. involvement in Brazilian police torture tactics. It also mentions that Virginia Louise Simmons Phillips' approval for Contract Type A employment was cancelled in September 1968.
title: Personnel Records: Phillips, Huff
